questions.text: Identify the associated with the following ECG?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atrial flutter Atrial flutter (AFl) Also k/as macro reentrant tachycardia Originate in right atrium Counter clockwise re entry Atrial rate 250-300, ventricular rate-125-150 ECG: Sawtooth P waves

Highyeild:

ECG Changes:- Narrow complex tachycardia Regular atrial activity at ~300 Beats per minute. Flutter waves ("saw-tooth" pattern ) best seen in leads lI, III, aVF - may be more easily spotted by turning the ECG upside down! Flutter waves in V1 may resemble P waves Loss of the isoelectric baseline

Extraedge:

Causes Of Atrial Flutter:- Coronary heart disease Atrial dilatation Open heart surgery Hypertension COPD Obesity Thyrotoxicosis Management of Atrial Flutter: - Medication - Control the ventricular response - Convert to sinus rhythm Anticoagulation Atrial overdrive pacing Cardioversion AV node ablation Isthmus RF ablation

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Deep venous thrombosis which is incorrect:

options.label: C
options.text: Most common clinically presents as pain and tenderness in calf

options.label: D
options.text: Some cases may directly present as pulmonary thromboembolism

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mostly bilateral Wells score or criteria: (possible score -2 to 9) Active cancer (treatment within last 6 months or palliative): +1 point Calf swelling = 3 cm compared to asymptomatic calf (measured 10 cm below tibial tuberosity): +1 point Swollen unilateral superficial veins (non-varicose, in symptomatic leg): +1 point Unilateral pitting edema (in symptomatic leg): +1 point Previous documented DVT: +1 point Swelling of entire leg: +1 point Localized tenderness along the deep venous system: +1 point Paralysis, paresis, or recent cast immobilization of lower extremities: +1 point Recently bedridden = 3 days, or major surgery requiring regional or general anesthetic in the past 12 weeks: +1 point Alternative diagnosis at least as likely: - 2 points

Highyeild:

Investigations Laboratory: CBC, Coagulation profile, ESR, LDH, ABG D-dimer:- Sensitive but not specific Up to 80% of ICU patients have elevated D-dimer in the absence of VTE More than 500 Mg/mL Alveolar-Arterial 02 Gradient:- A-a 02 gradient = Pa02 (alveolar) - Pa02 (arterial) Gradient > 15-20 is considered ECG:- S1Q3T3 Imaging Investigations:- Chest X-Ray Findings In Patients With Pulmonary Embolism. Atelectasis Parenchymal infiltrates Elevated diaphragm (both unilateral and bilateral) Enlarged hilum Enlarged mediastinum Cardiomegaly (in chronic PE) Pleural effusion Oligemia (Westermark's sign) Prominent central pulmonary artery ( Fleischner sign ) Pleural-based area of increased opacity ( Hampton's hump ) Pulmonary edema

Extraedge:

Occlusion of a pulmonary artery (ies) by a blood clot. Results from DVTs that have broken off and travelled to the pulmonary arterial circulation. Risk Factors:- VTE is most prevalent in three clinical conditions: Major surgery (particularly if it is cancer related or involves the hip or knee) Acute stroke Major trauma (especially spinal cord injury)

Table:

#MANTRA Initial Treatment Long-Term Treatment Extended Treatment Unfractionated heparin Low-molecular-weight heparin Fondaparinux Thrombolysis Percutaneous mech- anical embolectomy Surgery Vitamin K antagonists Vitamin K antagonists (INR target, 2.0-3.0) Vitamin K antagonists (INR target, 2.0-3.0 or 1.5-1.9) > 5 Days ≥3 Mo Indefinite

questions.text: Risk factors for Alzheimer’s disease include:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Down’s syndrome Alzheimer’s Disease The most common cause of dementia in the elderly is AD . Risk factors – Old age Low education Positive family history Female sex Past h/o head trauma with concussion Aluminium, Mercury Toxicity Viruses, Prion Genetic Factors – Down’s syndrome, APP gene on chromosome 21 Present – 1 gene on chromosome 14 Present – 2 gene on chromosome 1 Apo E 4 gene on chromosome 19 (Single most important biological marker) Apo E 2 gene on chromosome 14 (Protective for Alzheimer's) Increase blood homocysteine level Diabetes

Highyeild:

Pharmacological intervention Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors -prevent the breakdown of acetylcholine , a chemical messenger important for learning and memory Donepezil Rivastigmine Galantamine Memantine - blocks the NMDA receptor and inhibit their overstimulation by glutamate (neurotransmitter) Antidepressants. Anxiolytics. Antipsychotics. Anticonvulsants

Extraedge:

Pathophysiology:- DUE TO THE ETIOLOGICAL FACTORS ⬇️ CHANGES OCCUR IN THE PROTEINS OF THE NERVE CELLS OF THE CEREBRAL CORTEX ⬇️ ACCUMULATION OF NEUROFIBRILLARY TANGLES AND PLAQUES GRANULO VASCULAR DEGENERATION ⬇️ LOSS OF CHOLINERGIC NERVE CELLS ⬇️ LOSS OF MEMORY, FUNCTION AND COGNITION

questions.text: Which of the following is included in essential major blood culture criteria for infective endocarditis:
questions.correct_answer: B. Single positive culture of Coxiella
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Single positive culture of Coxiella The Modified Duke Criteria for the Clinical Diagnosis of Infective Endocarditis Major Criteria Positive blood culture Typical microorganism for infective endocarditis from two separate blood cultures. Viridans streptococci, Streptococcus gallolyticus, HACEK group organisms, Staphylococcus aureus, or Community-acquired enterococci in the absence of a primary focus, or Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or Phase I IgG antibody titer of >1:800 Evidence of endocardial involvement by positive echocardiogram Vegetation Abscess New partial dehiscence of prosthetic valve, New valvular regurgitation (increase or change in pre-existing murmur not sufficient) Minor Criteria Predisposing heart conditions or injection drug use Fever ≥38.0°C (≥100.4°F) Vascular phenomena: Major arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions. Immunologic phenomena: Glomerulonephritis, Osler’s nodes, Roth’s spots, rheumatoid factor Microbiologic evidence: positive blood culture but not meeting major criterion, as noted previously, or serologic evidence of active infection with an organism consistent with infective endocarditis Criteria of How to diagnose: Definite infective endocarditis: 2 major Or 1 major and 3 minor Or all 5 minor criteria (if no major criterion is met).

Highyeild:

Diagnosis ↑ TLC ↑ ESR Blood cultures: 3 sets of Blood sample -Every 1 hr gap-In Acute Endocarditis 3 sets of Blood culture -each separated by 6 hrs gap -In subacute endocarditis TransThoracic ECHO TransEsophageal ECHO: - Done in non-diagnostic TTE - Suspecting complications (Abscess) - Intracardiac lead. - Staph.aureus bacteremia - Prosthetic valve CT Scan - done in Peri aortic valve involvement Duke's criteria for IE: Major Criteria Positive blood cultures Typical pathogens from at least two separate cultures Evidence of endocardial involvement by echocardiography Endocardial vegetation, perivalvular abscess, new partial dehiscence of prosthetic valve, new vavular regurgitation Minor Criteria Predisposition Heart condition or IV drug use Fever Greater than or equal to 38°C Microbiologic evidence Single positive blood culture (except for coagulase-negative staphylococcus or an organism that does not cause endocarditis) Vascular phenomena Arterial emboli, mycotic aneurysm, septic pulmonary infarcts, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions Echocardiographic findings Consistent with endocarditis, but does not meet major criteria

Extraedge:

Organisms in I.E Staph aureus Streptococcus viridans Enterococci In Acute I.E Staph aureus SubAcute I.E Viridans Enterococci HACEK. In neonates - Staph aureus In i.v drug abusers Staph aureus (valve involvement R > L side) If (R) side valve -+ Staph aureus If (L) side valve - Enterococci aureus In Prosthetic valve: <2 months - CONS (Staph epidermidis) > 12 months - Strep. Viridans In colon cancer -Strep.bovis

questions.text: A man who is Chronic Alcoholic will develop which type of cardiomyopathy:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dilated cardiomyopathy It is a condition in which the heart's ability to pump blood is decreased because the heart's main pumping chamber, the left ventricle, is enlarged or weakened. Alcoholic cardiomyopathy is a disease in which the chronic long-term abuse of alcohol (ie ethanol) leads to heart failure. Alcoholic cardiomyopathy is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy. Causes of DCM: Infection Viral- Cox Sackie, Adeno, HIV Bacterial - Diphtheria Parasitic – Trypanosoma Non infectious Sarcoidosis Pregnancy Hyperthyroidism Diabetes Thiamine deficiency Selenium deficiency Alcohol Cocaine Adriamycin Duchenne muscular dystrophy

Highyeild:

SIGNS :- Abnormal S3 and S4 sound Tachycardia or bradycardia Edema Pulmonary crackles Weak peripheral pulses Hepatomegaly Jugular venous distention DIAGNOSTIC MEASURES History Echocardiography Chest x-ray: shows the signs of cardiomegaly ECG: reveals tachycardia, bradycardia and dysrhythmias . Cardiac catheterization : it is performed to confirm CAD

Extraedge:

PATHOPHYSIOLOGY Characterized by diffuse inflammation and rapid degeneration of myocardial fibers ⬇️ ventricular dilation ⬇️ impairment of systolic function ⬇️ Atrial enlargement and stasis of blood in the left ventricle ⬇️ cardiomegaly

Table:

#MANTRA

Solution:

Serum creatinine The Model for End- stage Liver Disease (MELD) It is a prospectively developed and validated chronic liver disease severity scoring system that uses a patient’s laboratory values for – Li Serum bilirubin Serum creatinine. The international normalized ratio (INR) for prothrombin time to predict three month survival. Patients with cirrhosis , and increasing MELD score is associated with increasing severity of hepatic dysfunction and increased three-month mortality risk. Given its accuracy in predicting short-term survival among patients with cirrhosis, MELD was adopted by the United network for organ sharing (UNOS) in 2002 for prioritization or patients awaiting liver transplantation in the United states. MELD (model for end stage liver disease): Bilirubin, Creatinine, INR CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh’s) score: Albumin, bilirubin, ascites, encephalopathy, INR OKUDA: Bilirubin, albumin, tumor size, Ascites

questions.text: Which of the following murmur increases on standing?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HOCM Effect on murmur: Valsalva: All decreases except MVP and HOCM Squatting: All increases except MVP and HOCM Standing: All decreases except MVP and HOCM Hand Grip Exercise: All increases except MVP, HOCM

Highyeild:

Maneuvers that ⬇️ end-diastolic volume:- (V venous return & afterload, 1 contractility) Vasodilators Inotropes Dehydration Valsalva Amyl nitrite Exercise ⬆️ HCM murmur

Extraedge:

HOCM:- left and/or right ventricular hypertrophy , usually asymmetric and involves the interventricular septum. Histology: Myocardial fiber disarray, endocardial plaques. Abnormal relaxation and diversely oriented myocardial fibers. Intimal hyperplasia of intramural coronary arteries, endothelial dysfunction, myocardial perfusion defects. Physical exam: Apex localized , sustained Palpable S4 Tripple ripple Prominent "a" wave Rapid upstroke carotid pulse, " jerky" bifid ( spike-and-dome pulse) Harsh systolic ejection murmur across entire precordium > apex & heart base MR : separate murmur: severity of MR related to degree of outflow obstruction

Table:

#MANTRA Murmurs Inspiration & Expiration Increased Preload Rapid squatting, Passive leg raising) Decreased Preload (Valsalva, Standing) Increased Afterload (Handgrip) Decreased Afterload (Amyl nitrite) Most murmurs ↑ Most murmurs on inspiration; Left-sided murmurs on expiration ↑ Increase ↓ Decrease Stenotic murmurs (except MS): ↓ Regurgitant murmurs: Stenotic murmurs (except MS): ↑ Regurgitant murmurs AS ↑ on expiration ↑ Increase ↓ Decrease ↓ Decrease ↑ Increase MVP No effect ↓ Decrease with later onset click ↑ Increase with early onset ↓ Decrease with later onset click ↑ Increase with early onset click HOCM No effect ↓ Decrease ↑ Increase ↓ Decrease ↑ Increase

questions.text: A 20 year old patient presented with breathlessness and chest pain. His vitals were BP: 80/60mmHg, Pulse: 105, spO2: 91%. Next line of management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cardioversion The ECG shown is of Paroxysmal Supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Repeated episodes of tachycardia with an abrupt onset and ending (paroxysmal) ST is usually due to a reentry mechanism. Could also be to abnormal automaticity or triggered activity but would have more of a warm-up and cool-down effect. Since his vitals are not stable , DC shock has to be given. Adenosine should have been the answer if the patient was stable .

Highyeild:

Rate is 150-300 , regular , p often hidden Atia is pacemaker (may got see p waves) reentrant phenomenon

Extraedge:

Causes :- SNS stimulation, MI CH Sepsis

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Which of the following nail findings is seen in the condition shown below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pitting Nail pitting may show up as shallow or deep holes in your nail nails Nail changes: Koilonychia - Spoon shaped nail. Onycholysis - Psoriasis Pterygium - Lichen Planus, Raynaud's Mees line - Arsenic Beau's lines - Trauma, Drug, Fever Lindsay nail - Uremia White nail/Terry nail - Anemia, Hypoalbuminemia Blue nail - Wilson Black nail - Peutz Jeghers syndrome

Koilonychia Indented spoon shaped IIron deficiency Hemochromatosis (too much iron) Ravnaud's disease Lupus erythematosus Pitting Dents on the Nails Psoriasis Eczema Reactive arthritis Alopecia areata

Extraedge:

Clubbing:- Unusually curved fingertip & nails COPD CF Lung cancer IBD Endocarditis Bronchiectasis Cirrhosis Polycythemia Stomach or bowel cancer

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the bundle of Kent?

options.label: B
options.text: It is muscular or nodal pathway between the atria and ventricle in WPW syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: It is slower than the AV nodal pathway

questions.correct_answer: B. It is muscular or nodal pathway between the atria and ventricle in WPW syndrome
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is muscular or nodal pathway between the atria and ventricle in WPW syndrome The Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is Characterized by presence of an accessory pathway ( bundle of Kent between atria and ventricle that can cause " pre-excitation " or earlier activation of the His-Purkinje system. ECG Features:- Inconduction through normal pathway normal PR interval normal QRS complex conduction through accessory pathway PRinterval < 120 m Slurred upsloging of Qwave (Delta wave)

Highyeild:

The diagnosis of atrioventricular pre-excitation in sinus rhythm is established on the association between:- a short PR interval , a wide QRS , a delta wave , a normal terminal QRS portion and frequent repolarization disorders.

Extraedge:

Pathway Associated Arrhythmia Atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) commonly occurs in WPW where the reentrant circuit is formed through the accessory pathway Orthodromic AVRT:- Impulse travels down the AV node and up the accessory pathway Antidromic AVRT:- Impulse travels down the accessory pathway and up the AV node

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Osborn J waves is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypothermia Osborn / Camel hump wave Positive deflection in terminal. Part OF QRS complex Prominent on anterior and lateral precordial leads and in lead II Cause people suffering from hypothermia with a temperature of less than 32°C (90°F) and hypercalcemia.

Highyeild:

Osborn waves (also known as camel-hump sign, late delta wave , hathook junction, hypothermic wave, prominent J wave ,1 K wave, H wave or current of injury) are an electrocardiogram finding. Osborn waves are positive deflections occurring at the junction between the QRS complex and the ST segment, where the S point, also known as the J point, has a myocardial infarction-like elevation.

Extraedge:

Causes:- They are usually observed in people suffering from hypothermia with a temperature of less than 32 C (90 F) , people with high blood levels of calcium ( hypercalcemia ) brain injury, vasospastic angina, or ventricular fibrillation. Complications of hypothermia Cardiac arrhythmias at temperatures below 30-32°C Infection Aspiration pneumonia Pulmonary edema Pancreatitis Bleeding diathesis Bladder atony Frostbite Electrolyte (hyperkalemia, hypoglycemia), hematocrit, coagulation study abnormalities

Table:

#MANTRA HYPOTHERMIA FIRST AID Move person to a warm place. Remove wet clothing. Warm center of the body first chest, head, neck and groin. Give warm beverages if conscious. Wrap body and head in a warm blanket. Administer CPR if unconscious.

questions.text: Punched out ulcer in esophagus is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herpes Simplex Virus Serpiginous - CMV - Biopsy from base of ulcer Punched out - HSV - Biopsy edge of ulcer

Highyeild:

The presence of an ulcer can be suspected on a barium swallow & confirmed endoscopically. Characteristically produce severe & unrelenting pain , often with radiation of the pain to the back. Brisk hemorrhage may be caused by erosion of an esophageal artery. The ulcer usually is in columnar (Barrett's) epithelium.

Extraedge:

Pathophysiology Abnormal lower esophageal sphincter Functional (frequent transient LES relaxation) Mechanical (hypotensive LES) Foods (eg, coffee, alcohol), Medications (eg, calcium channel blockers), Location:- hiatal hernia (x ray show gas behind the heart) Increase abdominal pressure

questions.text: Type of sensation lost on same side of Brown Sequard syndrome:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Proprioception Damage to one half of the spinal cord , resulting in:- paralysis and loss of proprioception on the same (or ipsilateral ) side as the injury or lesion. Loss of pain and temperature sensation on the opposite (or contralateral ) side as the lesion due to spinothalamic tract involvement.

Highyeild:

Clinical features on Same side Below the level of lesion - loss of proprioception, tactile discrimination, vibration, spastic paralysis and Babinski sign At the level of lesion - segmental flaccid paresis Clinical features on opposite side Loss of pain and temperature one or two levels below lesion Clinical Diagnosis Consider CT in case of trauma Consider MRI in case of tumor suspect

Extraedge:

Definition - hemisection of spinal cord, often in the cervical cord Causes- unilateral compression through trauma disc herniation, spinal epidural hematoma, spinal epidural abscess or tumor, multiple sclerosis, complication of decompression sickness.

Table:

#MANTRA

Solution:

Autosomal dominant Achondroplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Highyeild:

Achondroplasia: (Mnemonic: ACHONDROPLASIA) A: Autosomal dominant C: Champagne glass pelvis on X-ray H: Hand anomaly (Trident hand) O: Obesity N: Neurological problems D: Delayed motor milestones R: Recognized at birth O: Bowing of legs P: Proximal limb shortening LA: LArge head S: Short stature Interpedicular distance between vertebra decreases

questions.text: Infarcts involving which portion of the myocardium cause aneurysm as a post - Myocardial infarction complication:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterior transmural MI Left ventricular aneurysm formation: Left ventricular apical aneurysm formation usually occurs following antero-apical myocardial infarction, after LAD occlusion. This weakening of the antero-apical wall results in an outpouching or “ dyskinesis ” of the apex of the heart during systole .

Highyeild:

Diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) The criteria to label AMI are: Typical increase and gradual decrease in Cardiac Troponin-T Rapid rise in CK-MB and its fall Ischemic changes leading to symptoms ECG shows pathological Q-wave ECG shows ST-segment elevation or depression Coronary angiography will confirm the diagnosis. Outcome of AMI pathological changes

Extraedge:

Ventricular aneurysms are circumscribed , thin walled fibrous, non contractile outpouchings of the ventricle. An aneurysm is a severely scarred portion of infarcted ventricular myocardium that does not contract normally. A ventricular aneurysm may develop in some patients following a large MI (especially anterior). Instead, during ventricular systole the aneurysmal portion bulges outward while the rest of the ventricle is contracting. Ventricular aneurysms may occur on the anterior or Inferior surface of the heart.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Most characteristic cardiovascular defect seen in Rubella:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pulmonary artery stenosis The classic triad for congenital rubella syndrome is: Sensorineural deafness (58% of patients) , Eye abnormalities especially retinopathy, cataract , and microphthalmia Congenital heart disease especially pulmonary stenosis, VSD, ASD patent ductus arteriosus. Other findings are - Glaucoma, salt and pepper retinopathy.

Highyeild:

Diagnosis Of Rubella:-

Extraedge:

Rubella virus is spherical , 40- to 80 nm. hemagglutinin-containing surface projections An electron dense 30 to 35 mm core is surrounded by a lipoprotein envelope Clinical findings:- Malaise Low grade fever Morbilliform rash Rash starts on Face & Extremities Rarely lasts more than 5 days

questions.text: Which is not related to HIV:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tertiary syphilis Tertiary Syphilis has no relation to HIV status and primarily based on the duration of the infection and complications of Syphilis. Definitive AIDS Diagnose (with or without laboratory evidence of HIV Infection) Candidiasis of the esophagus, tractea, bronchi, or lungs. Cryptococcosis , extrapulmonary. Cryptosporidiosis with diarrhea persisting longer than 1 month Cytomegalovirus disease of an organ other than liver, spleen, or lymph nodes. Herpes simplex virus causes a mucocutaneous ulcer that persists longer than 1 month; esophagitis of any duration. Kaposi sarcoma in a patient younger than 60 years of age. Lymphoma of the brain (primary) in a patient younger than 60 years of age. Mycobacterium avium complex or Mycobacterium kansasii disease, disseminated (at a site other cervical or hilar lymph nodes). Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy. Toxoplasmosis of the brain

Highyeild:

STAGES OF HIV Stage 1 - CD4 count > 500 Stage 2 - CD4 count 200-499 Stage 3 - Cd4 count < 200 Symtomatic Stage (CD4 count thresholds for classic clinical manifestations) CD4 Count Possible Manifestations <500 cells/mm³ Often asymptomatic Constistitutional symptoms: fever, night sweats, fatigue, weight loss Mucocutaneous lesions: seborrheic dermatitis, HSV, (shingles), oral hairy leukoplakia (EBV), candidiasis (oral, esophageal vaginal), Kaposrs sarcoma (KS) Recurrent bacterial infecfions, especially pnetgno Pulmonary and enrapdmonary tuberculoss Lymphoma <200 cells/mm³ Pneumocystis jiroveci pneurnonia (formerly PCP) KS Oral thrush Local and/or disseminated fungal infections: Cryptococcus neoformans, Coccidioides immitis Histopbsma capsulatum <100 cells/mm³ Progressive multifocal leukoencephabpathy (PML) JC CNS toxoplasmosis <50 cells/mm³ CMV infection: retinitis, corms, cholangiopathy, CNS disease Mycobacteriun aviuw complex (MAC) Bacillary angiomatosis (disseminated Bartonella) Prnary central nervous system lymphoma (PCNSL)

Extraedge:

PRIMARY CNS LYMPHOMA Caused by EBV It is Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma 25:15 Clinical features: Seizures Focal deficits Altered mental status. Diagnosis: Brain Biopsy EBV - DNA PCR _> (+) Treatment: AntiRetroviral Therapy Radiotherapy ‡ Chemotherapy
